senses.definition: to think or believe that something is true because you have been told that it is

examples.x: I understand (that) you wish to see the manager.
Am I to understand that you refuse?
The Prime Minister is understood to have been extremely angry about the report.
It is understood that the band are working on their next album.

senses.definition: to agree something with somebody without it needing to be said

examples.x: I thought it was understood that my expenses would be paid.

senses.definition: to realize that a word in a phrase or sentence is not expressed and to supply it in your mind

examples.x: In the sentence ‘I can't drive’, the object ‘a car’ is understood.

senses.definition: the knowledge that somebody has about a particular subject or situation

examples.x: Students will gain a broad understanding of the workings of Parliament.
a deep/clear understanding of something
Unions said her comments showed a complete lack of understanding of what the civil service does.
She possesses a thorough understanding of the nature of the threat we are faced with.
The book aims to inform readers seeking a greater understanding of the issues involved.
The committee has little or no understanding of the problem.
to develop/improve/increase understanding of something
to contribute to/lead to an understanding of something
Most of the students have a sound understanding of English grammar.
The existence of God is beyond human understanding (= humans cannot know whether God exists or not).

senses.definition: the ability to understand why people behave in a particular way and to forgive them when they do something wrong

examples.x: Organizers of the rally say they want to promote understanding, tolerance and open-mindedness.
These efforts would foster mutual understanding and respect for different values.
We must tackle the problem with sympathy and understanding.
Try to show a little more understanding.
We are looking for a better understanding between the two nations.

senses.definition: an informal agreement

examples.x: We finally came to an understanding about what hours we would work.
We have this understanding that nobody talks about work over lunch.
I think I've reached an understanding with my mother.

senses.definition: the particular way in which somebody understands something

examples.x: My understanding of the situation is different.
It was our understanding that you had already been informed.
My understanding is that we're meeting him at the theatre.
The statement is open to various understandings.

senses.definition: to make yourself responsible for something and start doing it

examples.x: to undertake a task/project
University professors both teach and undertake research.
The company has announced that it will undertake a full investigation into the accident.

senses.definition: to agree or promise that you will do something

examples.x: He undertook to finish the job by Friday.

senses.definition: a task or project, especially one that is important and/or difficult

examples.x: He is interested in buying the club as a commercial undertaking.
In those days, the trip across country was a dangerous undertaking.
the first joint undertaking of the two societies

senses.definition: an agreement or a promise to do something

examples.x: a government undertaking to spend more on education
The landlord gave a written undertaking that the repairs would be carried out.

senses.definition: the business of an undertaker
joined together as a political unit or by shared aims

examples.x: the United States of America
efforts to build a united Europe
a politically united federation

senses.definition: in agreement and working together

examples.x: We need to become a more united team.
They are united in their opposition to the plan.
The two parties were united in insisting on keeping the two regions of the Sudan together.
The various religious and ethnic groupings were united by their desire to end British rule.
The EU has sent a clear message that it stands united against terrorism.
In contrast, the Republican Party is united behind its candidate.

senses.definition: used in the names of some teams and companies

examples.x: Manchester United
United Biscuits

senses.definition: the state of being in agreement and working together; the state of being joined together to form one unit

examples.x: European unity
a plea for unity within the party
unity of purpose

senses.definition: the quality of looking or being complete in a natural and attractive way

examples.x: The design lacks unity.
the organic unity of Raphael's picture

senses.definition: any of the principles of classical or neoclassical theatre that limit the action of a play to a single story, day and place

examples.x: the unities of action, time and place

senses.definition: a single thing that may consist of a number of different parts

examples.x: If society is to exist as a unity, its members must have shared values.

senses.definition: the number one
to advise or try hard to persuade somebody to do something recommend

examples.x: If you ever get the chance to visit this place, I strongly urge you to do so.
Police are urging anyone who saw the accident to contact them immediately.
She urged him to stay.
I urge people to vote yes on May 5.
The charity urged the government to reconsider its decision.
The authorities urged residents to stay indoors.
The NFU is urging its members to support the proposed scheme.
The police are urging anyone with new information to come forward.
The report urged that all children be taught to swim.
‘Why not give it a try?’ she urged (him).

senses.definition: to recommend something strongly

examples.x: The situation is dangerous and the UN is urging caution.
EU foreign ministers urged an independent inquiry into allegations of human rights violations.
The prime minister is urging restraint on Washington.
He urged a tax increase upon congress as a way of damping down consumer spending.

senses.definition: to make a person or an animal move more quickly and/or in a particular direction, especially by pushing or forcing them

examples.x: He urged his horse forward.

senses.definition: to go against or refuse to obey a law, an agreement, etc.

examples.x: to violate international law

senses.definition: to upset or not respect somebody’s peace, privacy, etc.

examples.x: She accused the press photographers of violating her privacy.

senses.definition: to damage or destroy a holy or special place

examples.x: to violate a grave

senses.definition: to force somebody to have sex

examples.x: He had drugged her and then violated her.

senses.definition: the act of going against or refusing to obey a law, an agreement, etc.

examples.x: They were in open violation of the treaty.

senses.definition: the act of not respecting somebody's rights, peace, privacy, etc.

examples.x: gross violations of human rights

senses.definition: the act of damaging or destroying a holy or special place

examples.x: This was a violation of a sacred space.

senses.definition: the act of forcing somebody to have sex
a person, government, etc. that goes against or refuses to obey a law, an agreement, etc. or does not respect somebody's rights

examples.x: The law is strictly enforced and violators punished.
notorious human rights violators

senses.definition: a person who forces somebody to have sex
a written agreement in which a company selling something promises to repair or replace it if there is a problem within a particular period of time

examples.x: The television comes with a full two-year warranty.
Is the car still under warranty?

senses.definition: to persuade somebody to give you something or do something by saying nice things that you do not mean

examples.x: The kids can always wheedle money out of their father.
She wheedled me into lending her my new coat.
‘Come on, Em,’ he wheedled.

senses.definition: to get somebody to change their opinion about something and give you their support and approval

examples.x: She's against the idea but I'm sure I can win her over.

senses.definition: to get somebody to change their opinion about something and give you their support and approval

examples.x: She's against the idea but I'm sure I can win her over.

senses.definition: to get somebody to change their opinion about something and give you their support and approval

examples.x: She's against the idea but I'm sure I can win her over.

senses.definition: to rub something against a surface, in order to remove dirt or liquid from it; to rub a surface with a cloth, etc. in order to clean it

examples.x: Please wipe your feet on the mat.
He wiped his hands on a clean towel.
She was sniffing and wiping her eyes with a tissue.
He wiped his plate clean with a piece of bread.

senses.definition: to remove dirt, liquid, etc. from something by using a cloth, your hand, etc.

examples.x: He wiped the sweat from his forehead.
She wiped off her make-up.
Use that cloth to wipe up the mess.

senses.definition: to remove information, sound, images, etc. from a computer, video, etc.

examples.x: You must have wiped off that programme I recorded.
Somebody had wiped all the tapes.

senses.definition: to deliberately forget an experience because it was unpleasant or embarrassing

examples.x: I tried to wipe the whole episode from my mind.
You can never wipe out the past.

senses.definition: to try to persuade somebody to agree to something or to do something

examples.x: He hasn't said he'll do it yet, but I'm working on him.

senses.definition: usually used as an order to tell somebody to stop talking or causing trouble, etc.
to include a rule or condition in a contract or an agreement when it is made

examples.x: A penalty clause was written into the contract.
He had an extra clause written into his contract.

senses.definition: a person who always agrees with people in authority in order to gain their approval
to produce or provide something, for example a profit, result or crop

examples.x: Higher-rate deposit accounts yield good returns.
The research has yielded useful information.
These trees no longer yield fruit.
The project is expected to yield good returns in future.

senses.definition: to stop resisting something/somebody; to agree to do something that you do not want to do

examples.x: After a long siege, the town was forced to yield.
He reluctantly yielded to their demands.
I yielded to temptation and had a chocolate bar.

senses.definition: to allow somebody to win, have or take control of something that has been yours until now

examples.x: He refused to yield up his gun.
The universe is slowly yielding up its secrets.
archaeological remains which are yielding up secrets from long ago

senses.definition: to move, bend or break because of pressure

examples.x: Despite our attempts to break it, the lock would not yield.

senses.definition: to allow vehicles on a bigger road to go first

examples.x: Yield to oncoming traffic.
a yield sign

senses.definition: to be the most successful in a competition, race, battle, etc.

examples.x: Which team won?
to win an election
to win a game/race/war/battle
She loves to win an argument.
to win at cards/chess
France won by six goals to two against Denmark.

senses.definition: to get something as the result of a competition, race, election, etc. one

examples.x: Britain won five gold medals.
He won £3 000 in the lottery.
How many states did the Republicans win?
Everyone who takes part wins a small prize.
to win an award/a title
The Conservatives won the seat from Labour in the last election.
You've won yourself a trip to New York.

senses.definition: to achieve or get something that you want, especially by your own efforts

examples.x: They are trying to win support for their proposals.
The company has won a contract to supply books and materials to schools.
She won the admiration of many people in her battle against cancer.
